thread.title: Trolltunga photos removed after fatal fall
thread.title_full: Trolltunga photos removed after fatal fall

title: Trolltunga photos removed after fatal fall
text:
Trolltunga photos removed after fatal fall Last updated 09:17, September 14 2015 
Kristi Kafcaloudis died after falling hundreds of metres while posing for a photo at Trolltunga Rock in Norway. 
Norway is removing pictures from its tourism website of people posing dangerously on the iconic Trolltunga cliff after an Australian's death there. 
Kristi Kafcaloudis, a 24-year-old Melbourne student, was killed after reportedly losing her balance and falling 700 metres from the "troll's tongue" ledge while preparing to pose for a photograph. 
Innovation Norway spokeswoman Marianne Mork said it was the first known fatal accident at Trolltunga. 
Ms Mork said tourism offices, including Visit Norway, offered a wide range of information about security in the Norwegian mountains, but "unfortunately, accidents do happen". 
"It can - as we have recently seen - be extremely dangerous. The walk up there is also pretty hard, and many tourists are not prepared for that part either." 
The number of people who completed the four-hour trek to Trolltunga increased from 500 in 2009, to 40,000 last year, and images appearing on social media seem to have raised the bar for dangerous stunts for photos.
